posts.name: Abu
posts.cooked: You should create a poll for this because it will be easier. Anyway, command-based all day.

posts.name: Steve
posts.cooked: At this point, I don’t see a reason for not using command based. IMO, it’s more readable, intuitive, and understandable.

posts.name: Eric Ward
posts.cooked:
For me it’s often all of the above.

The Command framework is effectively just a way to define a state machine.

Whenever I need a more a complexly defined state machine, I implement that by adding conditions to triggers or having conditional commands.

Or sometimes I’ll have a subsystem which is implemented as a state machine internally and commands are used as a way to trigger events within it.

I will say the one downside to command-based is that it’s specific to WPILib and it can really mystify new programmers who struggle to understand what code is asynchronous.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
bathtubed:

I will say the one downside to command-based is that it’s specific to WPILib and it can really mystify new programmers who struggle to understand what code is asynchronous.

I’d like to write an frc-docs article explaining asynchronous programming and drawing parallels to Promises/Futures at some point before next year to help with this.

posts.custom_user_title: Robot apartments! invisible suburbs! skeleton treasuries!

posts.name: John Bottenberg
posts.cooked:
What is the kind of programming where everything is just mappings and conditionals in TeleopPeriodic? I guess with auto being a simple state machine.

Not that my team does exactly that, but I’ve mentored teams that have done this in the past. In my experience it’s the easiest thing to teach, if starting a programming team from square one.

posts.name: coderkevin
posts.cooked: Big fan of Command based programming here. In fact, we’ve been moving our remaining robot state into commands more as we go, and our co-driver has a cancel button that cancels all active commands, which has been helpful for avoiding consequences from both software bugs and mechanical issues.
